items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns miscellaneous surplus property that has been determined to be of no further use to the District (see attached Surplus Disposal Forms, 3 pages). The estimated aggregate market value of the surplus property is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
Purchasing Services will call for competitive bids on the Public Surplus website and sell the items to the highest responsive bidders. Proceeds will be deposited to the District's general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey. Interim Director. Purchasing Services, extension 6165
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the surplus property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous District Surplus Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 3. Sale of Miscellaneous District Surplus Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has 11 pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (See attached Surplus Forms, 23 pages). The District's Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District. In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers. Proceeds will be deposited to the District's general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey. Interim Director. Purchasing Services, extension 6165
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 4. Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns miscellaneous property that has been replaced with new. The property has been determined to be in such poor condition that it is unusable. District staff estimates the resale value to be less than $50.00 in the aggregate.
	 
California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey. Interim Director. Purchasing Services, extension 6165
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the items are of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to recycle the items or dispose of them in the local public dump.
items.item_text: Recycle and Dispose of District Property
items.item_text_raw: 5. Recycle and Dispose of District Property

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for new Stand Alone Courses for the 2013-14 Catalog.  Per Title 5 direction, every course that is not part of a State approved degree or certificate or is not part of the Foothill General Education Requirements is required to have completed an application to substantiate its appropriateness to our mission, prove that it has met Foothill’s curriculum standards and that it is compliant with regard to enrollment restrictions and accreditation standards.
	 
These courses have completed College Curriculum Committee applications and have been approved through the established Foothill curriculum process.
	 
Submitted by:
  Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
  Kimberlee Messina, Carolyn Holcroft
Is backup provided?
  Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill Administration recommends approval of the Stand Alone courses for the 2013-2014 catalog.

Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill seeks board approval for curriculum changes for the 2013-14 Catalog.  Per Title 5 direction, all course changes, substantial and non-substantial, must be approved by the governing board of the District before they may be submitted to the State Chancellor's Office for final approval.
	 
These courses have met Foothill’s curriculum standards and the Foothill College Curriculum Committee certifies that they are compliant with Title 5 regulations.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College will contract with the Philippine Government to present a fully customized pedagogical program focused on training educators throughout the Philippines in the use of today’s technology to transform student learning across the country.  This program is designed to create a fully customized educator professional development program for teachers and educators throughout the Philippines.
	 
This partnership is the collaboration between the district Contract Education Office at Foothill College, the pedagogical design and instructional team at the Krause Center for Innovation, and delegates of the Philippine Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) led by Philippine Congresswoman Rachel Arenas. 
	 
This is a comprehensive 9-month program which includes pedagogy development, curriculum and courseware design, customization of content focused on the use of technology in teaching the current Philippine National STEM curriculum,  an intensive faculty-led 2-week training program in Santa Barbara, Pangasinan, Philippines, development of a professional learning community website, video cameras for each participant, and a 6-month mentorship project that will follow nearly 4,000 educators as they incorporate the proven tools, programs, content and techniques that will help them transform the way they teach, and the way their students learn, for generations to come. 
	 
The pedagogy and coursework are to be developed by KCI, under the leadership of Steven McGriff. The planning, budgeting, and management of the program will be lead by Contract Ed. Rushton Hurley, from KCI, will lead the instructional team from KCI. Judy Miner will lead the launch of the training program in the Philippines, and represent Foothill College with local (Filipino) media and dignitaries.
	 
Foothill College will receive $263,000 for the Customized Philippine Training Program.
	 
Submitted by:
  Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
  John Mummert, Reg Duhe
Is backup provided?
  Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill Administration recommends approval of the contract for the Customized Philippine Training Program.
items.item_text: Contract for Customized Philippine Training Program
items.item_text_raw: 9. Contract for Customized Philippine Training Program

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Approval is sought for renewal of the Whittier Center and Alfred WAC facilities for the 2013-14 District’s HOPE program. 
	 
The renewal is in accordance with the attached “Agreement for the Use of Facilities Owned or Leased by Hope Services” effective July 1, 2013 through June 30, 2014.
	 
The original Hope lease was entered into on July 1, 2007 for a one-year period. Section three of this agreement stated “This agreement may be extended for additional one-year terms by the mutual written consent of the parties”.
	 
The lease amount remains the same as the previous year: $7,634/month ($91,608/year).
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy, President, ext 8705
Additional contact names:
Letha Jeanpierre, Vice President Finance & Educational Resources ext. 8976
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Presented for review and first reading are changes proposed to align the board policy regarding student trustees (BP 9110.1) with the language set forth in the California Education Code and recommended by the Community College League of California's policy and procedure service. The related administrative procedure is included for information.
	 
Both board policy 9110.1 and Education Code Section 72023.5 require that the Board of Trustees adopt rules and regulations each year by May 15 regarding student trustee privileges.  The Board of Trustees will be asked to approve the revised policy at the May 13, 2013, regular meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, extension 6104
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The California Community College Trustees (CCCT) Board of Directors is conducting an election between March 10 and April 25 to fill seven vacancies for three-year terms on the Board. The Board of Trustees, as a body, is entitled to submit one vote for each of the seven vacancies.  Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The student trustees may cast advisory votes to be used to resolve any ties that result in more than seven candidates being selected.
	 
A list of the 15 candidates who have been nominated as well as candidate nomination forms and statements of candidacy are attached.
	 
The results of the election will be announced at the CCCT Annual Conference, which is being held May 3-5 in Lake Tahoe.  
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board vote for seven candidates to fill three-year terms on the California Community College Trustees Board of Directors.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Student trustee Vincent Mendoza was unable to attend the regular Board of Trustees meeting of March 11, 2013, due to participation in the League for Innovation in the Community College Innovations 2013 conference in Dallas, Texas. As stated in Education Code §72024(d):
	 
A member may be paid for any meeting when absent if the board, by resolution duly adopted and included in its minutes, finds that, at the time of the meeting, he or she is performing services outside the meeting for the community college district, he or she was ill or on jury duty, or the absence was due to a hardship deemed acceptable by the board. The compensation shall be a charge against the funds of the district.
	 
Included for adoption by the Board is a resolution verifying the circumstances of student trustee Mendoza’s absence as required by Education Code Section 72024(d).
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, Chancellor, extension 6104
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt the resolution pursuant to Education Code Section 72024(d).
items.item_text: Resolution Authorizing Trustee Absence for Vincent Mendoza (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 14. Resolution Authorizing Trustee Absence for Vincent Mendoza (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
RESOLUTION ELECTING TO BE SUBJECT TO SECTION 22895 OF THE PUBLIC EMPLOYEES' MEDICAL AND HOSPITAL CARE ACT TO ESTABLISH A HEALTH BENEFIT VESTING REQUIREMENT FOR FUTURE ANNUITANTS
On July 2, 2012 the Board acted to approve a Resolution Electing to Establish a Health Benefits Vesting Requirement for Future Retirees Under the Public Employees' Medical and Hospital Care Act, which established a 60-year vesting threshold for the employer (District) minimum monthly contribution to CalPERS. This Resolution affected all represented employees of the District, including the Association of Classified Employees (ACE), California School Employees Association (CSEA), Faculty Association (FA), Operating Engineers Local 3 (OE3), and Teamsters (Supervisors), and all non-represented employees of the District, including Administrators (including Academic, Program and Executive Administrators) and Confidential Employees.
	 
CalPERS has reviewed the District's prior Board Action which established and authorized this Vesting Requirement and has  requested that the Board reaffirm its Resolution to clarify the effective date of the Vesting Requirement.  The attached Resolution clarifies that the effective date of the Vesting Requirement shall be May 17, 2012, in accordance with the Memorandum of Understanding signed by the members of the Joint Labor Management Benefits Council, also attached.
	 
Submitted by:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity x6211
Additional contact names:
Suzanne Pfeiffer, Director of Human Resources x6109
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity and Chief Negotiator recommends approval.
items.item_text: Ratification of CalPERS Health Benefits Plan Resolution – Vesting Requirement Effective May 17, 2012
items.item_text_raw: 16. Ratification of CalPERS Health Benefits Plan Resolution – Vesting Requirement Effective May 17, 2012

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In accordance with the Pension Reform Act and the PERS and STRS regulations, the salary schedules have been revised to include pensionable earnings for the individual bargaining agreements and handbooks for the following:
	 
California School Employees Association and Its Chapter 96, for Unit A (CSEA)
	 
Association of Classified Employees (ACE)
	 
Operating Engineers, Local 3 (OE3)
	 
Teamsters, Local 287
	 
Faculty Association (FA)
	 
Administrative Management Association (AMA)
	 
Confidentials
	 
The hourly, monthly and/or annual rates included in each of the Salary Schedules remain unchanged. In addition, the other types of compensation now included on the Schedules is also unchanged; however, per Pension Reform, these other types of compensation must now be reflected on the Salary Schedules rather than residing exclusively in other portions of the Agreement or Handbook. The Schedules reflect those other types of compensation deemed to meet the definition of “pensionable compensation” in accord with Pension Reform, such as longevity awards, shift differential pay, service recognition awards, professional growth awards, retention incentives, professional achievement increments, doctoral stipends and administrative achievement awards.
	 
Submitted by:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity x6211
Additional contact names:
Suzanne Pfeiffer, Director of Human Resources x6109
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity, and Chief Negotiator recommends approval

Background and Analysis:
	 
The Joint Labor Management Benefits Council – comprised of representatives of each of the bargaining units and non-represented employee associations, the District and Retirees – has met to study and review the current benefit plans and projected cost increases for the 2014 Benefits Plan Year.
	 
The JLMBC has recommended the following changes in Employee/Retiree Contributions effective January 1, 2014 – December 31, 2014. The District shall continue to contract with CalPERS as its health benefits provider and shall implement the recommendations reached with and ratified by the participating unions of the JLMBC. A copy of the JLMBC Memorandum of Understanding is attached.
	 
The following shows the change in contributions from 2012/2013 to 2014.

Part-time Faculty 2014
The CalPERS Select plan shall be the “basic” plan, all other plans shall be a “buy-up,” and
Kaiser rates shall be partially subsidized through December 31, 2014.  The benefits shall have three load thresholds, each with a respective District contribution to the premium cost.  For employees with loads of .4 up to .499, the District shall be responsible for payment of forty percent (40%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other plan options.  For employees with loads of .5 up to .599, the District shall be responsible for payment of fifty percent (50%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other plan options.  For employees with loads of .6 up to .67, the District shall be responsible for payment of sixty percent (60%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent
under the other plan options. The employee shall be responsible for the remainder of the monthly plan premium for the coverage elected.
	 
(Will be applied to the rate schedule in effect on January 1, 2014)
	 
Part-time Faculty 2013
The benefits provided under Article 22A shall have three load thresholds, each with a respective District contribution to the premium cost.  For employees with loads of .4 up to
.499, the District shall be responsible for payment of forty percent (40%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other plan options.  For employees with loads of .5 up to .599, the District shall be responsible for payment of fifty percent (50%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other plan options.  For employees with loads of .6 up to .67, the District shall be responsible for payment of sixty percent (60%) of the Select monthly plan premium or the dollar equivalent under the other
plan options. The employee shall be responsible for the remainder of the monthly plan premium for the coverage elected.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Foothill-De Anza Community College District (the “District”) anticipates that it could experience a cash flow shortfall during fiscal year 2013-14 created by timing differences between its anticipated expenditures and estimated receipt of revenues.  Resolution No. 2013-11 being presented to the Board of Trustees authorizes a short-term borrowing by the District to address this cash flow shortfall through the issuance of a tax and revenue anticipation note (a “TRAN”).
	 
(a)        TRAN Resolution.  The resolution authorizes the issuance of a TRAN by the District in an amount not-to-exceed fifteen million dollars ($15,000,000) and the participation by the District in the Community College League of California Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note Program (the “Program”).  By participating in the Program, the District’s TRAN will be marketed together with TRANs of other California community college districts in order to attract investors.
	 
(b)       Form of Purchase Agreement and Trust Agreement.  The Resolution approves the forms of Note Participation Purchase Agreement (the “Purchase Agreement”) and Trust Agreement (the “Trust Agreement”) for the Program.  Pursuant to the Purchase Agreement, RBC Capital Markets LLC, the Underwriter of the Program, will agree to buy the TRAN from the District.  All the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the TRAN, the final execution copy of the Purchase Agreement will be prepared following this form.
	 
The Trust Agreement is signed by the Wilmington Trust National Association, as Trustee, and each participating district.  The Trust Agreement sets out instructions to the Trustee for the deposit and disbursement of (1) the funds received from the sale of the TRANs and (2) funds transmitted by the participating districts to repay their TRANs.  The Trust Agreement also sets forth the terms of the TRANs and the rights of investors.
	 
In order to participate in the TRAN program as sponsored by the Community College League of California, the Board of Trustees must adopt a resolution authorizing the borrowing of funds for the 2013-14 fiscal year.  The District is not obligated to participate as a result of resolution adoption.  The resolution simply delegates to the administration the authority to decide on participation prior to the time of the TRAN issuance.  The maximum amount of borrowing is not to exceed $15,000,000.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, ext. 6201
Additional contact names:
Hector Quinonez, ext. 6250
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: District administrative staff recommends approval and adoption of Resolution No. 2013-11 Authorizing the Issuance of a 2013-14 Tax and Revenue Anticipation Note.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Public Contract Code 20652 provides that the District may utilize contracts that have been awarded by other public entities. Western States Contracting Alliance (WSCA) is a contracting consortium for state government departments, institutions, agencies and political subdivisions in the states of Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Minnesota, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming.
	 
In fall 2012, WSCA entered into an agreement with six providers for wireless communication and equipment services that was publicly bid and awarded by the State of Nevada. WSCA Agreement No.1907 is valid through October 31, 2016. The WSCA contract pricing is posted at http://www.aboutwsca.org/contract.cfm/contract/w4-2001.
	 
On November 5, 2012, the board of trustees authorized a contract with Sprint Solutions, Inc. for wireless (cellular) services, radio services, equipment, and repairs based upon the terms and conditions of WSCA Agreement No. 1907 through June 30, 2013.  The board was also informed that District staff would evaluate the services and rates of the local providers that participated in the contract to determine whether there would be a benefit in switching services to a different provider.
	 
Pricing proposals for wireless communication and equipment services were solicited from all six of the providers who participated in the WSCA agreement. Facilities and Purchasing staff evaluated the proposals. Three of the providers did not offer the Push-To-Talk (PTT) radio feature, which is an essential function required to meet the District’s communication needs for the police, custodial, and facilities operations. The three providers who can provide PTT, cellular, and data communications are AT&T Mobility, Sprint Solutions, Inc. and Verizon Wireless.   
	 
A comprehensive cost comparison was analyzed between each of the three providers taking into consideration the initial cost of replacement equipment and the District’s current monthly-averaged PTT usage, cellular telephone usage, and data usage. All three providers can provide dependable coverage for PTT, cellular, and data communication in the San Francisco Bay Area.  Furthermore, ETS staff determined that smart phone compatibility with Outlook Exchange is satisfactory for all providers based upon the proposed equipment.   The proposal that was determined to provide the best value is from Verizon Wireless based upon the initial purchase price of equipment amortized over a two-year life cycle and the estimated annual cost for services. Although the initial cost for equipment is much greater for Verizon Wireless, the estimated averaged monthly cost for ongoing services plus the cost of equipment based upon a two-year life cycle is less than
AT & T Mobility and Sprint Solutions, Inc.
	 
For fiscal year 2013 – 2014, the estimated cost based upon current usage from each of the three responsive providers is summarized below:
	 
Provider
Averaged Monthly Service Cost based upon a two-year amortization of initial equipment 
FY 13-14 Estimated Annual Cost of Services 
AT&T Mobility
$10,089.35
$121,072.20
Sprint Solutions, Inc.
$6,803.82
$81,645.84
Verizon Wireless
$6,686.24
$80,234.88
	 
Submitted By:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional Contact Names:
Charles Allen, Exec. Director of Facilities & Const. Mgmt; Steven Schmidt, Facilities; Dawn Allshouse, Purchasing
Is Backup Provided:
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to issue purchase orders to Verizon Wireless for cellular services, PTT radio services, equipment, and repair based upon the terms and conditions of WSCA Agreement No. 1907 through October 31, 2016.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In January, 2012, the architectural firm of Lionakis was selected to provide design services for the Foothill – De Anza Educational Center at the former Onizuka Air Force Station, Measure C project #801. 
	 
Three previous agreements with Lionakis have authorized them to proceed with pre-design services to become familiar with this complex project, to provide programming services, and to prepare bidding documents for demolition of existing buildings on the site. 
	 
This agreement provides for professional services to design the required site improvements and the building itself.  Services include preparation of schematic design, design development and construction bid documents, bidding support services, provision of construction administration services, Green Building Council LEED certification and DSA closeout activities.  An allowance for reimbursable expenses is also included.   These services are to be provided for a fee not to exceed $1,913,395.  The estimated cost for site improvement and building construction is $20,000,000.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen x6150
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich x6295
Is backup provided?
Yes

This Change Order also includes a negotiated agreement for a sixty-nine (69) calendar day, compensable schedule extension for work associated with these floor box revisions (CCD 10), and associated RFI's 085, 125, 130, 131, 136, 152; and other additional scopes (CCD 005 - Surplus Furniture & Equipment; CCD 006 - RFI 48 - 1st Floor IDF Room Layout, RFI 089 - Mold Remediation and investigation; & RFI 119.2 - Add Ceiling in IDF Room 203q that may have had a schedule impact during this same period, however, they overlap with work associated with CCD 10.
	 
The total Change Orders to date represent 1.7% against the original contract amount.  Funding is included in the current budget.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
The project consists of a new emergency generator and related construction to replace the ageing existing generator that serves the Smithwick Theater and Building 1900.  The generator provides emergency power for life safety systems in the theater and for critical telephone and data equipment in Building 1900.  The replacement generator will be installed to the west of the existing generator to allow continuous emergency power and to allow space for the planned Fine Arts scene shop.  
	 
WRNS Studio prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
Bid #1625-115 was legally advertised on January 25, 2013 and February 1, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on March 5, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
GENERAL CONTRACTORS
BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
NEMA Construction
$299,000
Ray’s Electric
$331,000
RC Benson & Sons, Inc. 
$331,383
Angotti & Reilly, Inc. 
$348,000
Cal Pacific Construction, Inc.
$377,000
	 
	 
The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder is NEMA Construction (NEMA).  NEMA did not submit its signed Appendix A and Appendix C of the Project Stabilization Agreement (PSA) between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building Trades Council with its bid.  However, when requested NEMA immediately submitted its signed PSA documents to the Purchasing Services office.  Purchasing Services consulted with District’s legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret, regarding the missing documents.  It is his opinion that the failure of NEMA to include the requisite signed PSA documents with its bid, but a later curing of that shortly thereafter by NEMA with the executed documents, is a minor irregularity that can be waived by the District.  
	 
Furthermore, NEMA’s listed subcontractors have each signed the “Agreement To Be Bound” and the “Agreement of Contractors” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council.  
	 
NEMA has completed projects for other public entities such as Los Medanos Community College, San Francisco Unified School District, and the City of Concord. 
	 
The bid price of $299,000 submitted by NEMA exceeds the construction estimate of $275,000 for the emergency generator; however, it is within the overall Project 115 budget of $1,378,567.  Project 115  includes the Smithwick Emergency Generator and the Fine Arts Scene Shop project.  This project will be funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Waive the minor irregularity in the NEMA Construction response to Bid #1625-115, and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1625-115, Smithwick Emergency Generator Replacement in the amount of $299,000 to NEMA Construction.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1625-115, Smithwick Emergency Generator Replacement at Foothill College
items.item_text_raw: 26. Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1625-115, Smithwick Emergency Generator Replacement at Foothill College
